sec.p:
An increasingly popular technique, compound-specific stable isotope analysis of δ 15N in amino acids (CSIA-AA), holds promise for developing ecosystem indicators (
9 ). Embedded within the tissues of most organisms is a memory of their ecosystem experience (
10 ). Age, biogeography, diet, and other relationships can be described through a variety of tissue tracers (
11 –
14 ). CSIA-AA is unique in that it compares the relative enrichment of 15N to 14N (δ 15N) in trophic and source amino acids, building upon earlier bulk stable isotope methods, by yielding a robust and unbiased estimate of an organism’s trophic position (TP) (
9 ,
15 ). Applications of this technique to date, however, have largely addressed single species questions (
16 –
20 ) or food web models (
15 ,
21 ). CSIA-AA has not been applied to a fishery-independent data stream to assess marine ecosystem status over time or to test the various drivers of the observed trends.
